questions.question: Question 1: Preterm labour is defined as when the labour starts before
questions.explanation:
Preterm labour is defined as when labour starts before 37 completed weeks (<259 days) 
counting from the first day of the last menstrual period. Terminolog 
y Timing of deliver 
y <33 weeks 
Early prete 
rm 34 to 36 weeks 
Late preter 
m 37to 38 weeks 
Early term 39 to 40 weeks 
Full term

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is not a risk factor for preterm labour?
questions.explanation:
Progesterone intake is not a risk factor for preterm labour. Progesterone is used for prophylaxis of 
preterm labour. Risk factors for preterm labour: • Maternal history - • Previous history of spontaneous abortion or preterm delivery 423 
Sold by @itachibot • Artificial reproductive technique • Asymptomatic bacteriuria or recurrent UTI • Smoking • Maternal stress • Pregnancy complications - • Pre-eclampsia • Antepartum haemorrhage • PROM • Overdistended uterus - polyhydramnios, multiple pregnancy • Cervical incompetence • Uterine malformations • Intrauterine death • Maternal chronic diseases - • Hypertension • Nephritis • Diabetes • Severe anaemia • Periodontal diseases Option A: Multifetal pregnancies are common following artificial reproductive techniques and can 
be associated with preterm labour. Option B: Asymptomatic bacteriuria or bacterial vaginosis can cause spontaneous preterm labour. Option C: Chronic diseases like periodontal disease increase the risk of preterm labour.

questions.question:
Question 3: Late preterm births include births between  
.
questions.explanation:
Late preterm births include births between 34 to 36 weeks of gestational age. Terminolog 
y Timing of deliver

questions.question:
Question 4: A 31-year-old G3P2 woman presents at 29 weeks of gestation with a blood-tinged vaginal 
discharge. She is suspected to have preterm labour. Which of the following findings will not 
help confirm her diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
A cervical length of 32 mm (3 cm) does not help in confirming preterm labour as it is highly 
unlikely when the cervical length is >3 cm. The length of the cervix in preterm labour, as 
measured in transvaginal ultrasound is 2.5 cm. Preterm labor is the onset of labor before 37 completed weeks of pregnancy (less than 259 days of 
gestation). Features of preterm labor: • Uterus - regular contractions at least one in every 10 minutes, with/without pain • Cervix - dilatation >2 cm and effacement >80% • TVS - length of cervix <2.5 cm and funneling of the internal os >1 cm • Pelvic pressure, backache, vaginal discharge or bleeding PV Predictors of preterm labor: • Clinical predictors: • History of prior preterm birth • Multiple pregnancies • Presence of genital tract infection • Symptoms of preterm labour • Biophysical predictors: • Uterine contractions 4/hour • Bishop score 4 • Cervical length (TVS) 25 mm • Biochemical predictors: • Fetal fibronectin (fFN) in cervical/vaginal discharge >50 ng/mL • Increased levels of IL-6, IL-8, TNF-alpha The best predictors of preterm labor in a woman with a previous history of preterm birth are fetal 
fibronectin >50ng/ml and cervical length <2.5cm on TVS.

questions.question:
Question 5: Which of the following cannot be used to predict preterm labour in a patient having irregular 
uterine contractions at 30 weeks of gestation?
questions.explanation:
IL-2 is not a biochemical predictor of preterm labour. Biochemical predictors of preterm labor: • Fetal fibronectin • IL 6 425 
Sold by @itachibot • IL 8 • TNF Investigations of preterm labour: • Fetal fibronectin >50 ng/ml • TVS - length of cervix 2.5 cm • Urine culture • High vaginal swab • Maternal salivary estriol • Uterine activity monitoring

questions.question:
Question 6: A 30-year-old G2P1L0 woman came for a routine antenatal checkup at 20 weeks of gestation. 
She is worried about preterm labour as her previous baby was born preterm. What will be the 
timing and cut-off limit for fetal fibronectin (fFN) assay to predict this condition?
questions.explanation:
Fetal fibronectin value of >50 ng/mL in the cervicovaginal discharge between 24 and 34 weeks 
is predictive of preterm labor. Fibronectin is a glycoprotein that binds the fetal membranes to the decidua. It is normally found 
in the cervicovaginal discharge before 22 weeks and after 37 weeks of gestation. It is measured using an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. When the test is negative, it 
reassures that the delivery will not occur within the next 7 days.

questions.question:
Question 7: A pregnant woman presented with blood-tinged vaginal discharge at 35 weeks of gestation. A 
nitrazine paper test was performed on her. What is this test used to detect?

options.b: Fetal blood cells in Rh isoimmunisation

questions.explanation:
The nitrazine paper test is used to detect premature rupture of membranes. The nitrazine paper test detects the pH of the secretions from the vaginal pool. It turns blue at pH 
>6. Amniotic fluid is slightly alkaline with a pH of 7.1 - 7.3 and vaginal secretions have a pH of 
4.5 - 6.0. False-positive nitrazine test can be seen in contamination of the discharge with blood, semen, and 
bacterial infections. The below image shows the nitrazine paper. 426 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: Fetal hemoglobin in vasa previa is detected by Apt test. Option B: Estimation of the volume of fetal blood entering the maternal circulation in Rh 
isoimmunisation is done by Kleihauer-Betke test. Option D: In abruptio placenta, the diagnosis is mainly based on clinical features.

questions.question:
Question 8: 417 
Sold by @itachibot A sample of the vaginal fluid from the posterior fornix of a patient gave a positive nitrazine 
paper test. Which of the following conditions does not give a false positive result?
questions.explanation:
Oligohydramnios shows a false negative nitrazine paper test. Nitrazine paper test detects the pH of the secretions from the vaginal pool. It turns blue at pH 
>6. Amniotic fluid is slightly alkaline with a pH of 7.1 - 7.3 and vaginal secretions have a pH of 
4.5 - 6.0. False-positive nitrazine test can be seen in contamination of the discharge with blood, semen, and 
bacterial infections. False-negative nitrazine test can be seen in the case of scanty amniotic fluid.

questions.question:
Question 9: Transvaginal sonography in a case of clinically suspected preterm labour revealed a short 
cervix and funnelling of the internal os. What is the shape of the cervix that is likely to be 
seen here?
questions.explanation:
U-shaped cervix is seen on tranvaginal sonography (TVS) in preterm labour. On TVS, the cervix should be assessed to determine whether funnelling (internal os width >5 
mm) is present. The following is a TVS image showing a V-shaped cervix: Inference Shape of cervi 
x T shaped 
Normal 427 
Sold by @itachibot Shape of cervi 
Inference

Funneling of internal os U shaped 
Incompetent osPreterm labo 
ur

questions.question:
Question 10: A multigravida presents with preterm premature rupture of membranes. According to RCOG 
guidelines, which of the following antibiotics is preferred for her?
questions.explanation:
According to RCOG guidelines, erythromycin is the preferred antibiotic in the case of PPROM 
(preterm premature rupture of membranes). Spontaneous rupture of membranes before the onset of labour between 28 to 37 weeks is called 
preterm premature rupture of membranes. If PPROM occurs between 28 to 34 weeks, prophylactic antibiotics and corticosteroids are given 
to the patient.

questions.question:
Question 11: A primigravida at 30 weeks of gestation presents with labour pains but her membranes were 
intact. You decide to start her on corticosteroids and a tocolytic. Which of the following drugs 
will not be useful in this case?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of preterm labour with intact membranes and 
progesterone is not used as a tocolytic in these cases. Progesterone can be used for the prophylaxis of preterm labour in women with a previous history 
of spontaneous preterm labour. Glucocorticoid therapy is given in preterm labour when the period of gestation is <34 weeks to 
hasten fetal lung maturity. Short term therapy with tocolytics is given in conjunction with steroids 
for 1-3 days to delay labour for at least 48 hours or to transfer the patient to a tertiary centre (with 428 
Sold by @itachibot NICU). Tocolytics that can be given as short term therapy include: • Terbutaline • Magnesium sulphate • Indomethacin • Nifedipine • Atosiban

questions.question:
Question 12: A primigravida at 32 weeks of gestation was admitted for management of preterm labour. 
Which of the following tocolytics would be preferred for this?
questions.explanation:
Nifedipine is the preferred tocolytic as it has minimum maternal side effects. According to ACOG guidelines, the use of tocolytics in preterm labour does not prolong gestation 
but may delay delivery upto 48 hours. Hence, short-term therapy with tocolytics is given for 1-3 
days to delay labour for the action of corticosteroid therapy or to transfer the patient to a tertiary 
centre (with NICU). Tocolytics used in preterm labour and their side effects: Tocolytics

questions.question:
Question 13: Which of the following is not a contraindication for tocolysis in a patient with preterm 
labour?
questions.explanation:
Placenta previa is not a contraindication for tocolysis. In placenta previa, nifedipine and 
magnesium sulphate are used as tocolytics. Contraindications to tocolysis: 429 
Sold by @itachibot • Chorioamnionitis • Preeclampsia/Eclampsia • Advanced labour • Fetal distress • Intra-uterine death • Congenital anomalies not compatible with life • Pregnancy >34 weeks • Abruptio placenta

questions.question:
Question 14: A G3P1A1 woman presents with preterm labour at 27 weeks of gestation. She tells you that 
her previous child who was born preterm developed cerebral palsy. Which of the following 
drugs can you use to reduce the incidence of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Magnesium sulphate has a neuroprotective effect and hence decreases the risk of developing 
cerebral palsy. Magnesium sulphate can be used for neuroprotection in preterm labour when the pregnancy is 
<32 weeks. The dose is 4 g IV over 20 mins followed by an infusion of 1 g/hr.

questions.question:
Question 15: A primigravida was administered tocolytics and corticosteroids for preterm labour. The 
following day, she suddenly started coughing and gasping for air. On examination, her BP 419 
Sold by @itachibot was 160/100 mmHg and SpO2 was 80% in room air. Which of the following drugs could have 
caused this?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute pulmonary edema which is a side effect of the 
tocolytic ritodrine. Acute pulmonary edema in pregnancy can be due to: • Non-cardiogenic causes - • Pre-eclampsia • Acute haemorrhage • Sepsis • Tocolysis with ritodrine and magnesium sulphate • Vigorous IV fluid therapy • Cardiogenic causes Tocolytics used in preterm labour and their side effects: Tocolytics

questions.question:
Question 16: Which of the following tocolytics can cause multiple fractures in the fetus if given for a 
prolonged duration?
questions.explanation:
Magnesium sulphate can cause multiple fractures and hypocalcemia in a preterm baby. The FDA warned against prolonged use of magnesium sulphate to arrest preterm labour. The 
antagonistic effect of magnesium lowers the calcium levels in the fetus. This causes bone thinning 
and fractures in fetuses exposed to the drug for more than 5 to 7 days.

questions.question:
Question 17: Post-term pregnancy refers to pregnancy continuing beyond  
.
questions.explanation:
ACOG defines post-term pregnancy as a pregnancy continuing beyond 42 completed weeks of 
gestation. For clinical purposes, a pregnancy continuing beyond 2 weeks of the expected date of delivery 
(> 294 days) is called a post-term pregnancy. Inaccurate LMP is the most common cause of misdiagnosis of post-term pregnancy. Hence, early 
ultrasound dating is important to determine fetal gestational age.

questions.question:
Question 18: A woman presented for an antenatal checkup 2 weeks past her EDD. Which of the following 
is not an etiological factor for her condition?
questions.explanation:
Maternal stress is associated with preterm labour, not post-term pregnancy. Etiological factors of post-term pregnancy are: • Inaccurate LMP • Heredity • Primiparity • Previous prolonged pregnancy • Sedentary habits • Elderly multipara 431 
Sold by @itachibot • Anencephaly • Placental sulphatase deficiency

questions.question:
Question 19: You have performed an artificial rupture of membranes in a primigravida for augmentation of 
labour. You note the amniotic fluid to be saffron-coloured. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Saffron-coloured amniotic fluid is seen in postmaturity.

questions.question:
Question 20: A newborn baby was found to have wrinkled, patchy skin, a long thin body and long nails. 
Which of the following could be a cause for his condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of postmaturity syndrome which can occur due 
to placental sulphatase deficiency. Etiology of post-term pregnancy: • Wrong dates - inaccurate LMP (most common) • Heredity • Previous prolonged pregnancy • Anencephaly • Placental sulphatase deficiency (leads to decreased estrogen synthesis) • Primipara/ elderly multipara Features of postmaturity syndrome in a newborn: • Wrinkled, patchy, peeling skin, particularly prominent on the palms and soles • Long, thin body suggesting wasting • Long nails • Eyes open and unusually alert • Looks old and worried Note: Placental aromatase deficiency causes disorder of sexual development of fetus.

questions.question:
Question 21: A G2P1L1 woman came for a routine ANC at 41 weeks of gestation. On examination, her 
Bishop score was 2. She was admitted for fetal monitoring and induction. Which of the 
following complications would you not anticipate in the fetus even if her pregnancy continues 
further?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, the pregnancy continuing further would cross 42 weeks of gestation and 
thus turn into a post-term pregnancy. Hypoglycemia is seen in a post-term neonate. Complications of post-term pregnancy: • During labour: • Fetal hypoxia • Labour dysfunction 432 
Sold by @itachibot • Macrosomia • Shoulder dystocia • Oligohydramnios • Cord compression • Birth trauma • Meconium aspiration • Intracranial haemorrhage • Following birth: • Meconium aspiration syndrome • Hypoxia • Hypoglycemia • Polycythemia • Neonatal convulsions

questions.question:
Question 22: A primigravida was admitted at 42 weeks for induction of labour. Which of the following 
conditions is she not at an increased risk for?
questions.explanation:
The risk of post-partum haemorrhage does not increase in post-term pregnancy. Complications of post-term pregnancy are due to placental insufficiency and placental ageing. It 
manifests as placental infarcts and calcifications. During post-term pregnancy, diminished 
placental function can cause oligohydramnios. Complications of post-term pregnancy are: • During labour: • Fetal hypoxia • Labour dysfunction • Macrosomia • Shoulder dystocia • Oligohydramnios • Cord compression • Birth trauma • Meconium aspiration • Following birth: • Chemical pneumonitis, atelectasis, pulmonary hypertension (due to meconium aspiration) • Hypoxia • Hypoglycemia 433 
Sold by @itachibot • Polycythemia • Neonatal convulsions

questions.question: Question 23: The term small for gestational age implies birth weight
questions.explanation:
Small for gestational age implies birthweight is <10th percentile for gestational age. With respect to the size, a newborn can be appropriate, small or large for gestational age. Birth weight 
Terminology <10th percentile 
Small for gestational age >90th percentile 
Large for gestational age Appropriate for gestational a 
ge Between 10th and 90th perce 
ntile

questions.question: Question 24: What is the normal pH of amniotic fluid?
questions.explanation:
The normal pH of the amniotic fluid is 7.1 - 7.3 The normal pH of the vaginal secretions is 4.5 - 5.5. In premature rupture of membranes (PROM), 
the pH of the vaginal secretions becomes 6 - 6.2 as the amniotic fluid mixes with it. This forms the 
basis for nitrazine paper test. 434 
Sold by @itachibot Gestational Trophoblastic Diseases
